summary: The significant horticultural crop, cauliflower (Brassica oleracea L. var. botrytis) is vulnerable to the excessive salt concentration in the soil, which contributes to its scaled-down growth and productivity, among other indices .

The study examines the efficacy of hydropriming, halopriming, and osmoprims on the physio-biochemical attributes and tolerance to salinity (100mM NaCl) in cauliflower under controlled conditions . The salinity has significant deleterious impacts on cauliflower seed germination, seedling growth, and photosynthetic attributes . Different priming  Salinity triggers adverse changes in biochemical, physiological, and metabolic processes in the growing seeds . Salinity can also alter the release of reserve nutrients and protein structural organization . The most susceptible stages to salinity are seed germination and seed establishment .

Brassica oleracea L.A. represents a popular cash crop and the second most economical cooked vegetable after potato of the family Brassicaceae . It is recognised as the chief nutrient-rich crop, including a broad variety of phytochemicals with health-promoting qualities such as antioxidants, polyphenols, flavonoids, vitamin C, carotenoids, and
Ed seeds were used as controls and seeds were stored in sealed polythene bags . The experiments included the following treatments: priming with TU (Thiourea) 1 mM, 3 mM and 5 mM .

Primed and nonprimed seeds were placed in Petri dishes (90 × 120 mm) with double-layered sterile filter paper moistened with sterilized water, and germinated at 25 ± 2 °C for two days in a dark room . Leaves were incubated in 1mg/ml DAB (3′3′- diaminobenzidine; pH 3.8) solution and kept at room temperature until a darker brown stain (produced by H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>.sub>-DAB polymerization) appeared .

Seed priming with PEG increased all germination parameters, and the relative values of most features were higher in the PEG treatments than in the other treatments . The germination attributes varied with different priming treatments, viz. hydropriming, halopriming, etc. under salinity stress .
PEG treatments had greater PC1 scores and were clustered on the right side of the PC1 axis . The lower scoring treatments were majorly on the left .

The 13 distinct priming treatments were classified into three groups in cluster analysis . The 1mM TU, HP, and 100mM NaCl treatments had a smaller effect on seed germination under salt stress than the other treatments . The 20% PEG and 30% Peg treatments were in the second group . The third group included the 5 mM proline, 20

Chl a, Chl b, and total chlorophyll were increased at 1.95 fold, 3.38 fold and 2.15 fold in Pro 10 mM, Pro 20mM and Pro 10mM . Carotenoid was highly increased (2 fold) on 20m PEG compared to all treatments .

Salt stress has been linked to ion toxicity and osmotic stress in cellular metabolic processes, resulting in lower turgor pressure due to increased negative water potential . Seed priming is the effective and ancient method to reduce the negative effects of various abiotic stresses . Increasing salt tolerance is one of the most important and difficult management tasks .
MDA content of seedlings sprout from prepared seeds decreased significantly, indicating that these seedlings were better protected against salt stress .
The growth of the free amino acid pool due to hydrolysis of protein during the osmotic adjustment process may account for the increase in total soluble protein under salt stress .

Seed priming enhanced accumulation of all soluble proteins under a variety of abiotic stressors . Future research should address the mechanism by which seed preparation increases total protein content . Halopriming was the least effective for pigment enhancement compared to other priming approaches .  Simple and affordable priming treatments such as hydro-, halo-, and osmo-priming can be used to improve the performance of cauliflower crops . Additional research on the beneficial effect of priming approaches will support the scalability of sustainable production and increased crop output .
